docs.title: Q. Why did my Gift Certificate not migrate?
docs.text:
Gift certificates must first be activated within BigCommerce before migration, meaning that, depending on the BigCommerce settings, the first environment created during the StagingPro installation may not include them.

You can still do a partial migration of gift certificates after the environment has been created by following these steps.

Step 1: Within BigCommerce, navigate to “Marketing,” “Gift Certificates,” and make sure that the “Enable Gift Certificates” is ticked.

images

go top

docs.title: Q. Why can't I move products without Brands and Categories?
docs.text:
Brands and Categories are dependencies of Products which means they go hand in hand with each other.

Although it is not necessary to have a product in a specific category and even brands are not compulsory StagingPro considers all three to be critical and will migrate all three by default.

When migrating products you will be presented with the following popup screen giving you the options available

You can choose to delete all existing data (brands, categories and products only) first before starting the migration. This means that a brand new catalogue will be created.

Option 2 is mostly for cases where you just need to update some data between environments. Any existing products, categories or brands will be left alone while only new, unsynchronised data will be migrated

go top

docs.title: Q. Can you pause or cancel a data migration after it begins?
docs.text:
Currently, it can not be paused or cancelled as the data migration will carry on till the process is completed. Our team will review this as a feature request in our development roadmap.

go top

docs.text:
Yes, they will migrate.

docs.title: GitHub Account Setup
docs.text:
If you use GitHub for code deployments, you can integrate it with StagingPro!

Under the ‘Settings’ > ‘Connect Repository’ tab, you will use the the ‘Connect to GitHub App’

Important:

There are 2 distinct authorisation types with this implementation of the GitHub App installation.

· Type 1: The GitHub user has write access to the repository and can install the App

· Type 2: The GitHub user has read access to the repository and has to request for approval to install the App

docs.title: GitHub App installation flow as follows:
Step 1: Create GitHub Account and Log In
docs.text:
Sign up or log in to GitHub.

Please note that a valid GitHub ID is mandatory. If you don’t have a GitHub id, you can get one for free by clicking here.

docs.title: Step 2: Create Organization and Repository
docs.text:
GitHub integration pre-checks: There are 3 important steps to cover in order to use your GitHub repository with StagingPro:

1. Check your GitHub repository is created under user type ‘Organisation’

The first thing to make sure of is that your repository is created under the user type ‘Organisation’ (https://github.com/settings/organizations) and not under a Personal Account type. If you do not yet have an organization account, then you can follow the GitHub documentation on this subject. To do this, navigate to your repositories and click “New.”

Enter a suitable “Repository Name” (as an example - StagingPro)

It is recommended that the repository should be ”Private.”Click “Create Repository”

2. Your GitHub repository should have already selected the ‘Add a README’ file, it must be selected. Otherwise you should create a new repo with the option checked. A file needs to exist in the repo, otherwise, StagingPro will not be able to create a branch and you will get an error during the StagingPro linking.

Note: The above should be validated, *before* you link your GitHub repository with your StagingPro environment

docs.title: Step 3: Linking your GitHub repository to StagingPro.
Type 1: GitHub user has app installation rights
docs.text:
1. Log in to StagingPro and click “Connect to GitHub App”

2. Click on the Authorise button

3. Then, select your Organisation

4. Select the radio button ‘Only select repositories’, choose the respective repo from the drop down picker and click ‘Install’

5. After redirection back to the StagingPro app, click the ‘Settings’ > ‘Connect Repository’ tab to see your connected repo

Note: Give 3-5 minutes for the base environment branches to be created, based on the number of channels available for each store

docs.title: Type 2: GitHub user does not have app installation rights
docs.text:
1. The requester (user without install rights) signs into StagingPro and clicks “Connect to GitHub App”

2. The requester clicks on the Authorise button

3. Then the requester selects the organisation where the App has to be installed

4. In this step, the requester selects the radio button ‘Only select repositories’, chooses the respective repo from the drop down picker and clicks ‘Request” button

5. After the request is submitted, the requester will see the following notification on the Settings → Connect Repository tab on the StagingPro app

6. Next, the approver (user with app install rights) signs into the GitHub login and clicks on the ‘Review request’ button

7. Approval: Subsequently, the approver selects the radio button ‘Only select repositories’, chooses the respective repo from the drop down picker and clicks ‘Approve & Install’

8. After approval, the requester will see the GitHub repo connected as shown below:

Note: Give 3-5 minutes for the base environment branches to be created, based on the number of channels available for each store

9. Rejection: In the event, the approver rejects the GitHub App installation request, the requester can log a ticket with the helpdesk portal to reset the connection.

Alert: Even if the approver rejects the request, GitHub leaves an entry in the GitHub apps list which needs to be uninstalled before logging a ticket with the helpdesk portal to reset the connection.

docs.title: Step 4: Add Team Members
docs.text:
Then click the ‘Add Team Member’ button to specify the team member email id’s for adding the respective team member(s) to the repo and use the ‘Change Permission’ button to update the repository permissions.

You will then see an ‘Add Team Member' popup, where you can specify the GitHub email ID and Git User ID

When adding a team member their GitHub id also needs to be entered in order to add the user to the StagingPro branch for your project.

Each environment you have created will be visible and you can now specify the kinds of permissions you want to apply. You also can create a branch in any of the environments for the particular user if a new environment was added after the fact.

These permissions are based on the GitHub documentation which can be found here.

Click Save, to add the team member

StagingPro will automatically create branches based on your linked environment setup in StagingPro. When you add Git users in the ‘Connect GitHub’ tab, it creates team member branches for each environment branch (e.g., Production, Staging, UAT etc.)

Please wait for 5-10 minutes for the branches to be created and for the theme file to be pulled into the respective user related branches

Code commits to the respective StagingPro branch, will show up in the History & Rollback > Code Deployment tab

Then click the “Add Team Member” button to specify the team member email id’s for adding a team member to the repo and use the ‘Change Permission’ button to update the repository permissions.

You can also view the Git Branch association from the Home page.

docs.title: Step 5: Remove User
docs.text: · To remove a user, click "Remove" in StagingPro. This action removes the user from StagingPro but not from GitHub.

docs.title: Step 6: Change Permissions
docs.text:
· Change user permissions by navigating to the user settings and modifying their access.

· By selecting “Change Permission,” you can give each team member access to individual staging environments. It is recommended that you restrict access to your production store to only those users who actually need it.

Please refer to the article - StagingPro Deployment workflow - which elaborates how to commit codes and deploy themes.

IMPORTANT: Github Actions and workflow processes should be assigned to your development team who will review and fix the notifications visible on the deployment logs. Once all log items are reviewed and fixed by your development team, the StagingPro code deployments will be successful.

docs.title: A few GitHub FAQs
docs.text:
Q1. After giving Admin access to StagingPro Git repository, I see some autogenerated code branches e.g., Productione347c1, so should I keep the names as they are?A1. Yes, that is correct. These environment branch names are autogenerated and required for code commit tracking. Please do not delete or rename these branches as it will affect the GitHub integration.

The branches are created -

i) per environment

ii) per channel

iii) per team member

Q2. What is the purpose of developer branches?A2. As best practice, developers are given their own branches so they can commit their codes to their own branch at the first instance, or for more frequent code commits at the developers convenience without affecting the environment branch.

Q3. Are there any benefits to using a developer branch over a more typical git feature branch (e.g. feature/TICKET-description-of-the-change)?A3. Yes indeed! The developer can commit to their branch first. Once the task is complete, they can merge the code from their branch to the environment branch. If many developers are working on a common task, they can commit codes to each of their individual branches without affecting the other developer branches. And can merge their code easily.

Q4. What purpose does the Main/Master branch serve in a typical setup? A4. Master branch is generally used as a buffer branch and is the default branch while creating a repo in GitHub. This master ‘buffer’ branch can be left as it is. Instead use the autogenerated active branches that is automatically (with a name such as Productione347c1) created during your GitHub integration and linking process.

Q5. Is there a way to export from Bigcommerce to Github through StagingPro, or do I need to download the current theme through storefront and upload it to Github separately?A5. As long as GitHub integration is connected and at a minimum, one team member user is added in the ‘Settings’ section, then yes - StagingPro automatically downloads the theme into the connected branch.

Q6. When I commit changes in Github, will those changes will appear as rollback options in StagingPro?A6. Correct. After the GitHub integration is set, commit changes are tracked and rollback options are visible on the deployments grid.

Q7. Can you explain how version control works for StagingPro with multiple development teams as part of existing CI/CD pipelines? A7. When you successfully configure the GitHub integration on your StagingPro tenant, your GIT commits will be visible on the ‘Code Deployment’ tab which displays incremental version numbers. The code branches are created i) per environment ii) per channel and iii) per repo team member. Refer the StagingPro Git Branch workflow section of this document. Under Settings > Status Notifications you can enable the Deployment Notifications checkbox for team notifications through i) Email ii) Teams and iii) Slack for shared visibility and effective collaboration.

Q8. Launching preview is not generating preview URL quickly, why?A8. Depending on the theme file size, generating the preview URL may take up to 5 minutes, as it requires launching a temporary server and installing the theme.

Q9. After approval, deployment is taking a lot of time. Why?A9. Deployment may take around 15 to 20 minutes, depending on the theme file size. This is because the app needs to create the theme bundle file and then upload it to BigCommerce.

Q10. When I add GitHub users via the settings panel in the app, What does this exactly do? I already have the dev team added to the main repo in GitHub so does this also need to be done?A10: When you install Staging Pro in your tenant, it creates a separate repository and separate branches; does not use your existing Git repository. When you add Git users in the ‘Connect GitHub’ tab, it gets associated with the separate repository created for Staging Pro.

Q11. Typically we use Dev branch where the developer first pushes, in the Staging Pro world should we consider staging-ENV to be our dev?A11: You can setup the environments, dependent on your company code flow process; Production and Staging if preferred. In this case, its ideal for codes to be committed and tested in staging before being moved to production.

Q12. We have some custom build actions, is there a way to run these via you or my flow should remain: PR merge [Develop] → Jenkins runs → Merge to staging-env, if pass.A12: Sure, as long as you make the code commit to the correct branch, it will show up in the History & Rollback > Code Deployment tab.

Q13. How do you then like to promote code changes from staging → Integration and Production? Still use merges in GitHub to the named branches or via the UI?A13: The flow that is mostly used is Integration → Staging → Production. The reverse flow will also work, as long as there is no code conflict.

Before installing StagingPro in your tenant, you need to create an organisation repository in GitHub and add StagingPro as an Admin collaborator. docs.title: How-to Topics
docs.text: Q. How to migrate products from v2 to v3 store using StagingPro?

docs.title: Q. How to migrate products from v2 to v3 store using StagingPro?
docs.text:
For customers seeking to move from V2 to V3, a high level outline of the steps followed, are listed below:

  1. A V3 Sandbox is created and linked to the merchants existing V2 Production store

  2. Using StagingPro, copy product data from V2 Production to the V3 Sandbox store

  3. Review and fix all issues on the V3 Sandbox store

  4. After all issues are fixed, request BigCommerce support to upgrade your existing V2 production store to V3 and delete old products there (maintenance page recommended before migration begins)

  5. Use StagingPro to push data (including Products, Brands and Categories) from the V3 Sandbox to the revised V3 Production store Note: If using any ERP or other downstream system that uses Product ID instead of SKUs, update the new Product IDs (although SKUs will remain same).

  6. Finally after migration is complete, remove maintenance page and your revised V3 Production store is ready

docs.title: StagingPro cannot migrate all parts of BigCommerce, and most issues are already known. Some are under development, while others depend on future BigCommerce updates.
Products
docs.text:
• Channel Assignment Required for Product Migration
  • Products not assigned to any channel affect both bulk and selective content migration; internal testing has confirmed this limitation.
  • If a product has no channel assignment, it will be excluded from migration tasks, which can lead to incomplete data transfer.

docs.title: Shared Modifier Options and Shared Variant Options
docs.text:
StagingPro does not currently support migrating Shared Modifier Options or Shared Variant Options. Regular modifier and variant options migrate correctly. BigCommerce is working on APIs for Shared Options (no confirmed ETA).

Customs Information is not part of the standard Product API and is not migrated.

docs.title: Orders
docs.text:
• Order IDs are incremental in BigCommerce, so migrated orders will have new numbers.
  • Destination store orders cannot be deleted, causing count to grow with repeated migrations.
  • Original order number storage is on the roadmap.
  • Orders migrate with statuses “as-is”.
  • Recommended: disable customer order notifications in Marketing → Transaction Emails.

docs.title: Widgets
docs.text: Widget migration is supported only for stores whitelisted for the new Page Widgets API (Selective Migration). Multi‑column widget layouts are not yet supported.

docs.title: Blog-type Pages
docs.text: BigCommerce API does not support migrating pages with blog page type. These must be created manually in the Control Panel.

docs.title: "The URL is duplicate" API Notification
docs.text:
Pages & Categories - Conflicts occur when Page URLs and Category URLs overlap. Ensure unique URL values.

Products - If no visible duplicate exists, BigCommerce Support may need to run an orphan URL cleanup.

docs.title: Multi‑Shipment Orders
docs.text: BigCommerce API allows only one shipment per order. Additional shipments are not migrated. Payment method becomes “Manual”.

docs.title: Incorrect Order Count
docs.text: Some orders cannot be created due to BigCommerce limitations. Issue under investigation.

docs.title: Complex Rules
docs.text: Complex product rules are not supported and may be added to the roadmap.

docs.title: Migrating Apps
docs.text: Only channel data stored in BigCommerce is migrated; app‑internal data cannot be migrated.

docs.title: Migrating Custom Scripts
docs.text: Scripts in Script Manager are not migrated.

docs.title: Migrating Metafields
docs.text: Metafields at Brand, Category, and Product levels can be migrated.

docs.title: Related Products
docs.text: Migration is supported.

docs.title: Migrating Custom Fields
docs.text: Product custom fields migrate correctly. Customer custom fields do not exist in BigCommerce except for B2B “Extra Fields”.

docs.title: Customer Custom Form Fields
docs.text: Migrated only if custom form fields also exist in the destination store. BigCommerce API does not create customer fields.

docs.title: Payment Methods
docs.text: Payment methods cannot be migrated currently.

docs.title: Gift Certificates
docs.text: Migrated only if “Enable Gift Certificate” is enabled.

docs.title: Images
docs.text:
• There is currently no BigCommerce API to move banners and home page carousel images. We are looking at alternative migration methods and hope to have a solution shortly. It is worth noting that images outside of the THEME/ Template folder cannot be migrated as of now.

  • BigCommerce has no API to move images from WEBDAV and Image Manager. Any images such as Carousel images used in the Cornerstone theme, will not automatically move using StagingPro. Those images can be moved manually from your side.

  • There is currently no BigCommerce API available for moving category image URLs. Once such an API becomes available, it will be considered for inclusion in our implementation roadmap.

Note

For product images to get migrated successfully, the image should not have any ‘spaces’ or '&' character in the name of the image file.

docs.title: Social Media Links
docs.text: BigCommerce API does not allow migrating these values.

docs.title: Category & Brand Landing Pages
docs.text: Not supported via API. Workaround: migrate Categories, Brands, Widgets, Widget Templates, and Pages.

docs.title: Category Template Layout File
docs.text: Ensure layout_file exists in the destination theme. Migrate theme, then categories.

docs.title: Data Dependencies
docs.text: Examples include product–variation and product–category relationships.

docs.title: Tax Classes
docs.text: Not currently available via API.

docs.title: Page Redirects
docs.text: 301 redirects are not migrated (planned future feature).

docs.title: Themes
docs.text: Themes are applied only to the default store.

docs.title: High Variant Count Product Issues
docs.text: Products with exceptionally high variant counts may return 500 errors. Requires BigCommerce engineering intervention.

docs.title: API Rate Limits
docs.text:
BigCommerce applies quota‑based rate limits refreshed every 30 seconds.

Plan Type Quota Enterprise / Enterprise‑Test By plan & resource Other sandboxes (Dev/Partner/Employee) By resource Pro 60k/hr (450 per 30s) Plus & Standard 20k/hr (150 per 30s)

docs.title: Customer Segmentation
docs.text: Planned roadmap item.

docs.title: Coupon Codes
docs.text: When migrating coupon codes, also migrate categories if dependencies exist.

docs.title: Promotions
docs.text: Automatic and coupon promotions migrate. However, API‑created or legacy promotions cannot be edited after migration—must delete and recreate in source before migrating again.

docs.title: Other Issues
docs.text:
For any additional issues, raise a support ticket.

Step 1: Plan your environments Also refer to Best practice naming conventions and testing guidance in your new StagingPro environments

Step 3: Link additional environments to Production To easily access all areas of your store’s backend admin Control Panel (including your Sandbox stores) you need Store Owner* access. *See the BigCommerce article for Store Owner User Role and Permissions

StagingPro comes with three license tiers.

For the Standard Tier two Staging Environments are provisioned in addition to the Production Store.

For the Plus Tier, three Staging Environments are provisioned in addition to the Production Store.

For the Premium Tier five Staging Environments are provisioned in addition to the Production Store.

The suggested best practice for naming the staging environents is as follows:

1st Staging website: Staging

2nd Staging website: UAT

3rd Staging website: Integration1

4th Staging website: Integration2

5th Staging website: Integration3

Before you start, you must plan your environments so it will be setup correctly in StagingPro

Doing so will help you to determine:

  • The correct environment names before linking/association tasks
  • Distinguish between production and non-production environments (as any migration tests must happen in non-production environments first)

docs.title: Best practice naming conventions and testing guidance in StagingPro environments
docs.text:
As best practice and to avoid confusion, you can use the following naming conventions to clearly label your StagingPro environments.

  • Production - use this name for your live store site which contains all finished and approved codes/data. This is the default system name and cannot be changed/altered to any other value
  • Staging - use this name for your pre-deployment site that is setup to mimic your live site configurations and used for your smoke tests before deployment to ‘Production'
  • UAT - use this name for your site configured to run as a production build with a separate database. Used by clients to check that feature requests are working as expected before deployment to ‘Staging’
  • Integration - use this name for your site configured for system integration tests and checks for functional/non-functional elements before deployment to ‘UAT’.
  • You can also label your integration environments with numeric values, e.g. Integration1, Integration2

Screenshot provided for ease of reference.

IMPORTANT!As an additional best practice, it is highly recommended to test migrations first to non-Production environments. This helps you to gain a better understanding of StagingPro’s functionality, while safely launching/reviewing your test migrations. Only after comprehensive testing and proper validation in non-Production environments, should you migrate data to a live Production environment.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Communication between team members is vital in any development project, and keeping in touch with teams working remotely and across different time zones is more important than ever. StagingPro has the native ability to send notifications to Slack (and other channels) each time a deployment event occurs.

docs.title: Setting up the Slack channel
docs.text:
This document assumes that you already have Slack installed in your organization. You will find detailed instructions here if you need assistance downloading and installing Slack.

Step 1: Click on the "…" next to the "Channels" menu item.

Step 2: Select "Create a channel" from the popup menu

Step 3: Give your channel a unique name and click "Create"

Step 4: If everybody in your organization is going to have access to the StagingPro notifications, then you can leave the default "Add all members of [your Slack name]" and click the "Add" button. Alternatively, type the user names of each individual you would like to be part of this channel and click "Add."

The new channel is created, and you will see it displayed in the left-hand menu.

docs.title: Creating the app
docs.text:
Before you can link StagingPro to Slack, we first need to create a connector (or webhook) that listens for incoming messages. To do this, we need to create an app.

Step 1: From a new browser window, go to api.slack.com

Step 2: Click the "Create an app" button.

Step 3: When the Create an app window appears, select "From scratch"

Step 4: Give your app a good name and choose your company's Slack workspace in the dropdown menu.

IMPORTANT: If the workspace dropdown is empty, you must go back to api.slack.com and log into Slack.

Step 5: Click on “Create App”

Step 6: Under "Add features and functionality," select "Incoming Webhooks" and click "Save Changes" at the bottom of the screen.

Step 7: Make sure that the "Activate Incoming Webhooks" toggle is set to "On" and click "Add New Webhook to Workspace" at the bottom of the page.

Step 8: A security message will appear asking your permission to access your Slack workspace. Use the dropdown menu to select the channel you created in Setting up a slack channel and click "Allow."

Step 9: Once redirected to the previous page, use the "Copy" button to add the newly generated link to the clipboard. Either paste this link somewhere you will find it again or continue to the next section.

docs.title: Connecting the app to StagingPro
docs.text:
Step 1: Open the StagingPro app, navigate to Settings, and then "Status Notifications"

Step 2: Click on "Add Channel" and select the "Slack" icon.

Step 3: Paste the URL you copied in the previous section into the Slack channel text box and click on Send Test Message.

Step 4: Provide a test message and click "Send"

Step 5: Go back to your Slack channel and make sure the message you have just sent has appeared.

docs.title: Creating a team in Microsoft Teams
docs.text:
Microsoft Teams allows you to specify different groups of people you regularly communicate with. Under each of these groups (known as “Teams”), communication is through smaller chats (known as channels). These channels allow users to communicate with individuals or larger groups within the team.

Before looking at channels, we must ensure that you have at least one team configured. If this is your first time using Microsoft Teams, there are three easy steps to follow when setting up a new team. You can find more detailed information on the Microsoft website by clicking here.

Step 1: Open Microsoft Teams. Click on “Teams” in the left-hand side panel.

Step 2: Click the “Create Team” button as indicated below

Step 3: Give your team a name. Please note that this name needs to be unique, but Teams will warn you if your name clashes with another name previously set up. Click “Next” when you are ready.

Step 4: Finally, we need to add team members. Start by typing the first few letters of a team member’s name, and Teams should display the desired user. Alternatively, you can enter a team member’s email address, and if this does not exist in teams, they will be allowed to join this team as a “guest.”

The image below shows that your team creation has been successful.

docs.title: Creating a new Teams channel
docs.text:
If you have followed the steps in the previous section, you would now have successfully set up a Team, so next, we need to take a look at creating a channel. Think about channels as separate “chat” windows between individuals or group of users within the team.

Step 1: To set up a channel, click on the “…” that you will see to the right of the name you have given to your team. When the popup menu appears, click on “Add Channel.”

Step2: Next, we need to give the channel a name. Once again, note that this has to be a unique name, but Teams will notify you if the name you choose clashes with a name previously created.

Your channel has now been created.

docs.title: Connecting your Teams channel to StagingPro
docs.text:
Now that you have both a Team and a channel, we need to link these to StagingPro so that notifications will be visible to everybody with access to the Teams channel.

Step 1: Hover over your new channel name until the “…” appear, and click this.

Step 2: From the popup menu that appears, click on “Workflows”

Step 3: Click on "Post to a channel when a webhook request is received"

Step 4: In the next screen that appears, enter the name of the workflow and click on next button

Step 5: Click on Add workflow button

Step 6: Copy and save the unique workflow URL present in the dialog. The URL maps to the channel and you can use it to send information to Teams. Select Done. The workflow is now available in the Teams channel.

Step 7: Open StagingPro, navigate to “Settings,” and click on the “Status Notifications” tab. Click on “Add Channels” and select the Microsoft Teams icon.

Step 8: Paste the previously copied link into the highlighted textbox and click “Send Test Message & Save”.

Step 9: Leave the default message, type your notification, and click send. You will see a notification window confirming that the message has been sent.

Step 10: Go back to teams and confirm that the test message has appeared in your new channel.

This option scrambles customer data from the source environment before migrating it to the destination environment, ensuring data security for testing purposes.

docs.title: Product Migration Notice
docs.text:
When performing a bulk migration of Products, you will see a popup describing the following option:

Add/Update Products Data (brands, categories, and products) from Source Store.

  • It will add missing products.
  • Existing items (same SKU and Name) will be ignored.
  • Click Continue Migration to proceed.

  • Entities without the icon have no dependencies and can be migrated independently.

docs.text: The Settings page is organized into the following tabs:

docs.title: 1. Connect Repository
docs.text:
In the Connect Repository tab, you can link your preferred Git repository for theme deployments. StagingPro currently supports the following integrations:

  • GitHub Integration
  • Bitbucket Integration

Important

The preferred authentication method is a Fine-Grained Access Token.

Warning

It is highly recommended to generate and use a GitHub Fine-Grained Access Token before connecting your repository to StagingPro.

docs.title: 2. Status Notifications
docs.text:
In the Status Notifications tab, you can configure how you want to receive notifications for:

  • Code deployments
  • Content migrations

You can receive notifications via:

  • Email
  • Microsoft Teams
  • Slack channels

docs.title: 3. Configuration Settings
docs.text:
The Configuration Settings tab displays the theme configuration values defined in the config.json file.

StagingPro automatically pulls the config.json from your BigCommerce store and syncs it to your connected GitHub repository. It also provides an interface to add custom configuration values, such as CRM/ERP URLs or keys.

By clicking Update config.json, you can:

  • Add or update configuration values
  • Specify URLs and API keys
  • Extend your theme configuration as needed

  • Control Panel — allows you to preview the backend Control Panel of the respective BigCommerce store environment

  • Data Migration & Theme Status — shows the migration start and end dates/times, along with a progress bar

Clicking the View More Details link displays:

  • migration status

docs.title: How Does Migration Work?
docs.text: The migration process follows these key steps:

docs.title: 1. Connect Your Stores
docs.text: You provide access credentials for both your source store (where data comes from) and destination store (where data goes). This uses secure BigCommerce connections.

docs.title: 2. Automatic Migration Type Detection
docs.text:
The platform automatically determines the migration type based on your store configuration:

Configuration

Migration Type

What Happens

Different stores

Full Migration

Complete product transfer with all components

Same store, different channels

Channel Migration

Simplified workflow - only channel-specific content

Multi-Storefront Note: If your source and destination are the same store but different channels (e.g., Retail to Wholesale), the platform uses a faster, simplified workflow since the product already exists. See Use Case 12 for details.

docs.title: 3. Select Products to Migrate
docs.text: Choose which products to migrate: - Single Product: Migrate one specific product by ID - Multiple Products: Migrate a list of specific products - All Products: Migrate your entire product catalog

docs.title: 4. Data Extraction
docs.text: The platform reads your source store product data, ensuring accurate and complete data retrieval including all components.

docs.title: 5. Intelligent Product Resolution
docs.text: Before creating products, the platform checks if matching products already exist in the destination store: - First, it searches by product name - If not found, it searches by SKU - If a match is found, the product is updated instead of creating a duplicate

docs.title: 6. Dependency Migration
docs.text: Related data is automatically migrated first: - Brands: If the product has a brand, it's created in the destination (or matched by name) - Categories: Full category hierarchy is recreated to maintain your catalog structure

docs.title: 7. Component Migration
docs.text: Each product component is migrated in the correct order: 1. Product base information 2. Images and videos 3. Options (Size, Color, etc.) 4. Variants (with correct option mappings) 5. Modifiers 6. Complex rules (conditional pricing/weight adjustments) 7. Custom fields 8. Bulk pricing rules 9. Reviews 10. Product and variant metafields 11. Widget templates 12. Locale-specific content

docs.title: 8. Locale Data Migration
docs.text: For multi-language stores, locale-specific content is migrated across 10 categories: - Basic information (name, description) - SEO data (page title, meta description) - Custom URLs - Option and modifier labels - And more...

docs.title: Duplicate Prevention
docs.text:
The platform automatically checks for existing products before creating new ones:

Check Order

Matched By

Result

1st

Product Name

If found, UPDATE existing product

2nd

Product SKU

If found, UPDATE existing product

Not Found

-

CREATE new product

Note: When updating an existing product, the platform backs up the original data first, allowing for rollback if needed.

docs.title: CREATE vs UPDATE vs CHANNEL Mode
docs.text:
Mode

When Used

What Happens

CREATE

Product doesn't exist in destination

New product created with all components

UPDATE

Product found by name or SKU

Existing product updated; old components replaced

CHANNEL

Same store, different channels

Only channel-specific content migrated (no components)

Channel Migration: When source and destination stores are the same, product components (options, variants, modifiers, etc.) are NOT migrated because the product already exists. Only categories, channel assignments, widgets, and locale data are transferred to the new channel.

docs.title: Component Cleanup (UPDATE Mode)
docs.text:
When updating an existing product, the platform first deletes all existing components before recreating them from the source. This is a replace strategy, not a merge.

Components deleted before migration:

Component

Cleanup Behavior

Images

All existing images deleted

Options

All options deleted (variants are auto-deleted with options)

Variants

Deleted when options are removed

Modifiers

All modifiers deleted

Custom Fields

All custom fields deleted

Bulk Pricing Rules

All pricing rules deleted

Videos

All videos deleted

Important: A backup is created BEFORE deletion, so you can rollback if needed. This ensures a clean slate for accurate data transfer from source to destination.

Note: Complex rules are handled intelligently - matching rules are preserved, and only redundant auto-generated rules are cleaned up.

docs.title: ID Mapping
docs.text: BigCommerce assigns new unique IDs when records are created. The platform maintains relationships through: - Options to Variants: Option value IDs are mapped correctly so variants link to the right options - Brands and Categories: Matched by name to preserve associations - Widget Templates: Template UUIDs are mapped between stores

docs.title: Fully Preserved
docs.text:
• Product names, descriptions, and all text content
  • All pricing (regular, sale, cost, retail)
  • Inventory levels and settings
  • SEO data (page titles, meta descriptions, search keywords)
  • Product images with alt text and display order
  • All option and modifier configurations
  • Complex rules with price/weight adjusters
  • Custom field values
  • Bulk pricing rules
  • Review content and ratings
  • Product and variant metafields
  • Multi-language locale overrides

docs.title: Automatically Regenerated
docs.text:
• Product IDs (BigCommerce assigns new IDs)
  • Option IDs and option value IDs (mapped automatically)
  • Variant IDs (linked to new options)
  • Image URLs (images re-uploaded to destination)

docs.title: Recommended Migration Order
docs.text:
For best results when migrating multiple products or your entire catalog:

  1. Products with shared brands - Brands are created once and reused
  2. Products in the same categories - Category hierarchy is built progressively
  3. Simple products first - Products without options or variants
  4. Complex products - Products with options, variants, and modifiers

Tip: The platform handles dependencies automatically, but understanding the order helps you plan your migration.

Note: These are estimates. Actual times depend on product complexity, image sizes, and number of variants.

docs.title: Automatic Backup
docs.text: Before updating any existing product, a complete backup is created. This includes: - Product base data - All options and variants - Modifiers - Custom fields - Bulk pricing rules - Videos

docs.title: Rollback Capability
docs.text: If something goes wrong during migration, you can restore the original product data from the backup.

docs.title: What's NOT Backed Up
docs.text:
• Images (only added, never modified)
  • Custom template associations (only created)

Scenario: A product already exists in the destination store, and you want to update it with data from the source store.
How Update Mode Works
Step 1: Product Resolution
Source Product: "Summer Dress Collection" (SKU: SDC-2024)

Destination Search:
1. Search by name "Summer Dress Collection" → Found! (ID: 456)
2. Mode: UPDATE (not CREATE)

Step 2: Backup Created Before any changes, existing product data is backed up: - Product base information - All options and variants - Modifiers and complex rules - Custom fields - Bulk pricing rules - Videos
Important: The backup ensures you can rollback if something goes wrong.
Step 3: Component Cleanup (DELETE Phase)
This is a critical step. In UPDATE mode, existing components are completely deleted before new ones are created. This is a replace strategy, not a merge.
Component
Cleanup Action
Images
ALL existing images deleted
Options
ALL options deleted
Variants
Auto-deleted when options removed
Modifiers
ALL modifiers deleted
Custom Fields
ALL custom fields deleted
Bulk Pricing Rules
ALL rules deleted
Videos
ALL videos deleted
Why delete everything? This ensures a clean slate and prevents orphaned data, duplicate entries, or mismatched IDs. The source data becomes the single source of truth.
Step 4: New Components Created Fresh data from source is created: - New options with new IDs - New variants linked to new options - New modifiers with new IDs - New complex rules with mapped modifier IDs - New custom fields - New bulk pricing rules - New videos - Product and variant metafields
Step 5: Images Added - Source images are uploaded fresh - Display order and alt text preserved

Understanding the Replace Strategy
Example: Before and After
Before Migration (Destination):
Product: Summer Dress Collection
Options: Size (S, M, L), Color (Red, Blue)
Variants: 6 variants
Modifiers: Gift Wrap, Custom Message
Custom Fields: Material, Care Instructions

After Migration (From Source):

Variants: 15 variants  ← More variants!
Modifiers: Gift Wrap, Rush Processing  ← Different modifiers!
Custom Fields: Fabric, Season, Designer  ← Different fields!

The destination product now exactly matches the source, regardless of what was there before.
Rollback Option
If the update causes issues: 1. Trigger rollback using migration ID 2. Original product data restored from backup 3. Product returns to pre-migration state
What gets restored: - Product base information - All original options and variants - Original modifiers - Original custom fields - Original bulk pricing rules - Original videos
What is NOT restored: - Images (only added, not modified) - Reviews (only added) - Custom template associations

  • Always verify source data before updating production products

Common questions about BigCommerce product migration.

What happens to my original store data?

Your source store data is never modified or deleted. The migration only reads data from your source store and creates copies in the destination store. Your source products remain exactly as they are.

How long does a migration take?

Migration time depends on your product complexity and catalog size:

Product Type

Approximate Time

Simple product (no variants)

5-15 seconds

Product with variants

15-30 seconds

Complex product (modifiers, custom fields, reviews)

30-60 seconds

Product with locale data

1-2 minutes

For bulk migrations:

Catalog Size

Approximate Time

10 products

5-15 minutes

100 products

30-60 minutes

500 products

2-4 hours

1,000+ products

Several hours

Note: Products with many images or variants take longer.

Can I migrate multiple times?

Yes! The platform uses duplicate detection—if a product already exists in the destination (matched by name or SKU), it's updated rather than duplicated. This means you can safely run migrations multiple times without creating duplicate products.

What if my migration fails partway through?

  • Already-migrated products remain in the destination store

  • The failed product can be retried individually

  • Detailed error information helps identify the issue

  • If updating an existing product, you can trigger a rollback to restore the original data

Can I rollback a migration?

Yes, for products that were updated (not newly created): - A backup is created before any changes - You can restore the product to its pre-migration state - Rollback restores: product base, options, variants, modifiers, custom fields, bulk pricing, and videos - Images are NOT rolled back (they're only added, never deleted)

What happens to existing product data when updating?

When a product already exists in the destination store (matched by name or SKU), the migration operates in UPDATE mode. This involves a complete cleanup of existing components before recreating them from the source.

Why does the platform delete existing components?

This ensures: - Clean slate: No orphaned or duplicate data - Accurate transfer: Source becomes single source of truth - Correct mappings: New IDs are properly linked (options to variants, modifiers to complex rules) - No conflicts: Prevents ID mismatches between old and new data

What gets deleted in UPDATE mode?

Component

What Happens

Images

ALL existing images deleted, then source images uploaded

Options

ALL options deleted (variants auto-delete with them)

Variants

Deleted when options are removed, then recreated

Modifiers

ALL modifiers deleted, then recreated from source

Custom Fields

ALL custom fields deleted, then recreated

Bulk Pricing Rules

ALL rules deleted, then recreated

Videos

ALL videos deleted, then recreated

What about complex rules during cleanup?

Complex rules are handled intelligently: - Matching rules: If a rule in destination matches source, it's preserved - Auto-generated rules: Single-condition rules (auto-created by BigCommerce) are cleaned up - Non-matching rules: Created fresh from source

Is my data backed up before deletion?

Yes! Before any deletion occurs: 1. Complete backup is created 2. Includes: product base, options, variants, modifiers, custom fields, bulk pricing, videos 3. Backup retained for rollback capability

Can I prevent the cleanup?

No. The cleanup is essential for accurate migration. However: - Backup protects you: Rollback available if needed - CREATE mode: If product doesn't exist, no cleanup needed - Test first: Migrate a sample product to verify results

What if I only want to update some fields?

Currently, migration is all-or-nothing for components. If you need selective updates: 1. Export the product data you want to preserve 2. Run the migration 3. Manually restore specific fields if needed

Tip: For partial updates, consider using BigCommerce's native import/export tools instead.

Will my product images transfer?

Yes. Product images are downloaded from your source store and re-uploaded to the destination store. This ensures: - Images are properly hosted in your new store - All image URLs work correctly - Alt text and display order are preserved

How is inventory handled?

Inventory levels are transferred directly: - Product-level inventory for simple products - Variant-level inventory for products with options - Inventory warning levels are preserved - Inventory tracking settings (none, product, variant) are maintained

What about products in multiple categories?

Product category assignments are fully preserved: - All category assignments transfer - Category hierarchy is recreated in the destination - If a category doesn't exist, it's created with the full parent path

Example:

Product in: Electronics > Computers > Laptops
All three categories created if needed, product assigned to "Laptops"
Are product metafields migrated?

Yes, both custom fields and metafields are migrated:

Custom Fields (displayed on storefront): - Field names and values preserved - Display order maintained

Metafields (key-value metadata): - Product metafields fully migrated - Variant metafields migrated to corresponding variants - Category metafields migrated when categories are created - Namespace and permission settings preserved

Note: App-specific metafields may require the same app installed in destination to be fully functional.

What happens to SEO data?

All SEO data transfers directly to help preserve your search engine rankings: - Page title - Meta description - Search keywords - Custom URL path

How are option values mapped?

When options are created in the destination store, BigCommerce assigns new IDs. The migration platform:

  1. Creates options in the destination (e.g., "Size" with values Small, Medium, Large)

  2. Records the mapping: Source ID → Destination ID

  3. Uses this mapping when creating variants

This ensures variants are correctly linked to their options.

What if a variant's SKU already exists?

If you're creating a new product: - All variants are created with their original SKUs - If a SKU conflict exists with another product, the variant creation may fail

If you're updating an existing product: - Old variants are deleted first - New variants are created with source SKUs

Are variant images preserved?

Yes. Each variant can have its own image: - Variant-specific images are migrated - Images are linked to the correct variant after migration - Main product images are also preserved

Yes, all pricing fields transfer exactly as configured: - Base price - Sale price - Cost price (your cost, hidden from customers) - Retail price (MSRP) - Variant-specific pricing overrides

How does bulk pricing work after migration?

Example:

Buy 10-24: 10% off
Buy 25-49: 15% off
Buy 50+: 20% off

All three rules migrate and work immediately.

What about inventory levels?

Do modifier price adjustments work?

Yes. Price and weight adjustments on modifier values transfer exactly: - Checkbox that adds $10 → Works in destination - Dropdown with different prices per option → All prices preserved

What about custom fields?

All custom fields migrate: - Field names preserved - Field values preserved - Display order maintained

Example:

Material: 100% Cotton
Care: Machine wash cold
Made In: USA

All three fields appear on the destination product.

What are complex rules?

Complex rules are conditional logic rules that trigger actions based on modifier selections. They can: - Adjust price when certain modifier combinations are selected - Adjust weight for shipping calculations - Disable purchasing for certain combinations - Display different images based on selections

Are complex rules migrated?

Yes! Complex rules are fully migrated with: - All conditions (modifier + value combinations) - Price adjusters (percent, fixed amount, or absolute) - Weight adjusters - Purchasing disabled flags and messages - Enabled/stop flags

How are modifier IDs handled in complex rules?

The platform automatically maps modifier IDs: 1. Modifiers are created first in destination 2. Source-to-destination ID mapping is captured 3. Complex rules are updated with new modifier IDs 4. Modifier value IDs are also mapped correctly

What if a complex rule references a modifier that wasn't migrated?

If a modifier ID in a rule can't be mapped: - A warning is logged - The rule may not function correctly - Check that all modifiers were successfully migrated

Do complex rules work immediately after migration?

Yes. Once migration completes: - Rules are active in destination - Price/weight adjustments apply on product pages - Purchasing restrictions are enforced

What about auto-generated complex rules?

Can I test complex rules after migration?

Yes! To verify complex rules work correctly: 1. Go to product page in destination store 2. Select modifier combinations that should trigger rules 3. Verify price/weight changes in cart 4. Test purchasing restrictions if applicable

Are product reviews migrated?

Yes, customer reviews are fully migrated: - Review title and content - Star rating (1-5) - Reviewer name and email - Original review date - Review status (approved, pending, disapproved)

Do review ratings calculate correctly?

Yes. After migration: - All reviews are attached to the destination product - Average rating is calculated from migrated reviews - Review count reflects total migrated reviews

Can I migrate reviews selectively?

Reviews are migrated as part of the product. If you migrate a product, its reviews come along. You cannot currently migrate only reviews without the product.

Are multi-language products supported?

Yes! The platform migrates locale-specific data across 10 categories:

  1. Basic Information - Translated name and description

  2. SEO - Locale-specific page title and meta description

  3. URL - Custom URL path per locale

  4. Options - Translated option names and values

  5. Modifiers - Translated modifier names and values

  6. Custom Fields - Translated field names and values

  7. Images - Locale-specific alt text and visibility

  8. Pre-Order - Translated pre-order messages

  9. Storefront - Warranty, availability, search keywords

  10. Channel Overrides - Featured status per channel

For each locale configured in your source store: - All text content that has locale-specific overrides - Locale-specific URL paths for SEO - Option and modifier label translations - Image alt text translations

Brands are matched by name: 1. Source product has brand "AudioTech" 2. Platform searches destination for "AudioTech" 3. If found: Uses existing brand 4. If not found: Creates new brand

What about category hierarchy?

Categories are recreated with full hierarchy:

Example:

Source category path: Electronics > Audio > Headphones
Migration creates (if needed):
1. "Electronics" (top level)
2. "Audio" (child of Electronics)
3. "Headphones" (child of Audio)
Product assigned to "Headphones"
Are category descriptions migrated?

When a category is created, only the essential information is migrated: - Category name - Parent relationship

Category descriptions, images, and SEO data are not part of product migration. For full category migration, a separate process would be needed.

What are widget templates?

Widget templates control how product page widgets appear. If your source product uses custom widgets, the template definitions are migrated to ensure the destination product displays correctly.

What about custom page templates?

If your source product uses a custom page template (e.g., product-special.html), the association is recreated in the destination.

Important: The template file itself must exist in your destination theme. Only the association is migrated, not the template file.

What happens when source and destination stores are the same?

When you migrate between channels in the same store, the platform automatically uses a simplified channel migration workflow. This is detected when: - Source store ID = Destination store ID - Source channel ID ≠ Destination channel ID

In this mode, only channel-specific content is migrated because the product already exists.

Why aren't product components migrated in channel migration?

In same-store channel migration: - The product already exists in the store - Options, variants, modifiers, etc. are store-level data, not channel-specific - Only channel-specific data needs to be set up for the new channel

What IS migrated: - Category assignments (to destination channel's tree) - Channel assignment (makes product visible) - Widget templates - Custom template associations - Locale data for the destination channel

What is NOT migrated: - Product base data (already exists) - Options and variants (store-level) - Modifiers and complex rules (store-level) - Images and videos (store-level) - Custom fields, bulk pricing, reviews (store-level)

Can I rollback a channel migration?

No, channel migration does not include backup/rollback because: - Nothing is deleted: Original product data unchanged - Non-destructive: Only adds visibility to new channel - Reversible manually: Remove channel assignment via BigCommerce admin

To "undo" a channel migration: 1. Go to BigCommerce admin 2. Edit the product 3. Remove the channel assignment for the destination channel

How fast is channel migration compared to full migration?

Channel migration is significantly faster:

Product Type

Full Migration

Channel Migration

Simple product

5-15 seconds

2-5 seconds

With locale data

1-2 minutes

15-30 seconds

Complex product

30-60 seconds

5-10 seconds

Will channel migration create a duplicate product?

No. Channel migration uses the same product ID. The product is simply made visible on an additional channel. You end up with one product visible on multiple channels, not multiple products.

Can I migrate to multiple channels at once?

Currently, you migrate to one destination channel per request. To publish a product to multiple channels: 1. Run channel migration for Channel A 2. Run channel migration for Channel B 3. And so on...

Each migration is fast, so publishing to multiple channels takes minimal time.

What about channel-specific pricing?

Channel migration does not change pricing. If you need different prices per channel: 1. First, run the channel migration to make the product visible 2. Then, use BigCommerce's channel-specific pricing features to set prices per channel

Does locale data differ between channels?

Yes! Each channel can have its own locale-specific content. During channel migration, locale data from the source channel is copied to the destination channel. After migration, you can customize locale content per channel.

"Product already exists" - is this an error?

No! This is expected behavior. It means: - A product with the same name or SKU was found in the destination - The platform will UPDATE this product instead of creating a duplicate - This prevents duplicate products in your catalog

Important: UPDATE mode will delete and replace existing components. See Component Cleanup for details.

Some product images didn't migrate - why?

Common reasons: - Source image unavailable: The image URL might be broken or inaccessible - Image too large: Very large images may timeout during download - Format issues: Some image formats may not be supported

Solution: Check the source product images are accessible and retry the migration.

My variants aren't showing the right options

This usually indicates an option mapping issue. Possible causes: - Options were modified in the destination after migration - Source product had inconsistent option values

Solution: Re-migrate the product to refresh the option mappings.

Modifiers aren't showing price adjustments

Verify that: 1. The source product had price adjustments configured 2. The modifier type supports price adjustments (some don't) 3. The adjustment values weren't zero

Complex rules not working after migration

Check the following: 1. Modifiers migrated: Complex rules depend on modifiers existing first 2. ID mapping: If modifier migration failed, rule conditions may reference invalid IDs 3. Rule enabled: Verify the rule's "enabled" flag is true 4. Conditions met: Test the exact modifier combination that should trigger the rule

Solution: Re-migrate the product to ensure modifiers and rules are properly linked.

Product not appearing on storefront

Check these settings: - Is Visible: Product visibility flag - Channel Assignment: Product must be assigned to the storefront channel - Category: Product should be in a visible category - Inventory: If tracking is enabled, verify stock quantity

Custom fields not displaying

Custom fields may not display automatically. Verify: 1. Custom fields were migrated (check product in admin) 2. Your theme is configured to display custom fields 3. The field names match what your theme expects

I lost data after updating a product - can I recover it?

If a product was updated (not created), a backup was taken: 1. Use the rollback feature with the migration ID 2. Original product data will be restored 3. Components restored: base data, options, variants, modifiers, custom fields, bulk pricing, videos

Note: Images and reviews are NOT rolled back (they're only added, never deleted).

Why are my destination product variants all gone?

In UPDATE mode, all options are deleted before migration, which automatically deletes all variants. This is expected behavior: - Variants are recreated from source - Inventory levels from source are applied - Option value mappings are fresh

If source had fewer variants than destination, only source variants will exist after migration.

Metafields from apps aren't working

App-specific metafields may require: 1. Same app installed in destination store 2. App to have matching client ID 3. Proper permission settings

If the creating app isn't installed, metafields exist but may not function as expected.

Before Migration

  1. Verify source data: Ensure products have complete data

  2. Check images: Confirm all image URLs are accessible

  3. Review inventory: Know your current stock levels

  4. Document custom templates: Note which templates your products use

During Migration

  1. Start small: Test with a few products first

  2. Monitor progress: Check migration status regularly

  3. Review results: Verify migrated products look correct

After Migration

  1. Spot check products: Review several products in detail

  2. Test purchasing: Add products to cart, check pricing

  3. Verify images: Confirm all images display correctly

  4. Check variants: Test option selection and variant switching

  5. Review SEO: Confirm page titles and meta descriptions

When contacting support, please provide: - Source and destination store identifiers - Product IDs you're trying to migrate - Any error messages you've encountered - Screenshots if applicable

We're here to help ensure a smooth migration!

In same-store channel migration: - The product already exists in the store - Options, variants, modifiers, etc. are store-level data, not channel-specific - Only channel-specific data needs to be set up for the new channel

What IS migrated: - Category assignments (to destination channel's tree) - Channel assignment (makes product visible) - Widget templates - Custom template associations - Locale data for the destination channel

What is NOT migrated: - Product base data (already exists) - Options and variants (store-level) - Modifiers and complex rules (store-level) - Images and videos (store-level) - Custom fields, bulk pricing, reviews (store-level)

Can I rollback a channel migration?

No, channel migration does not include backup/rollback because: - Nothing is deleted: Original product data unchanged - Non-destructive: Only adds visibility to new channel - Reversible manually: Remove channel assignment via BigCommerce admin

To "undo" a channel migration: 1. Go to BigCommerce admin 2. Edit the product 3. Remove the channel assignment for the destination channel

How fast is channel migration compared to full migration?

Channel migration is significantly faster:

Product Type

Full Migration

Channel Migration

Simple product

5-15 seconds

2-5 seconds

With locale data

1-2 minutes

15-30 seconds

Complex product

30-60 seconds

5-10 seconds

Will channel migration create a duplicate product?

No. Channel migration uses the same product ID. The product is simply made visible on an additional channel. You end up with one product visible on multiple channels, not multiple products.

Can I migrate to multiple channels at once?

Currently, you migrate to one destination channel per request. To publish a product to multiple channels: 1. Run channel migration for Channel A 2. Run channel migration for Channel B 3. And so on...

Each migration is fast, so publishing to multiple channels takes minimal time.

What about channel-specific pricing?

Channel migration does not change pricing. If you need different prices per channel: 1. First, run the channel migration to make the product visible 2. Then, use BigCommerce's channel-specific pricing features to set prices per channel

Does locale data differ between channels?

Yes! Each channel can have its own locale-specific content. During channel migration, locale data from the source channel is copied to the destination channel. After migration, you can customize locale content per channel.

Troubleshooting "Product already exists" - is this an error?

No! This is expected behavior. It means: - A product with the same name or SKU was found in the destination - The platform will UPDATE this product instead of creating a duplicate - This prevents duplicate products in your catalog

Important: UPDATE mode will delete and replace existing components. See Component Cleanup for details.

Some product images didn't migrate - why?

Common reasons: - Source image unavailable: The image URL might be broken or inaccessible - Image too large: Very large images may timeout during download - Format issues: Some image formats may not be supported

Solution: Check the source product images are accessible and retry the migration.

My variants aren't showing the right options

This usually indicates an option mapping issue. Possible causes: - Options were modified in the destination after migration - Source product had inconsistent option values

Solution: Re-migrate the product to refresh the option mappings.

Modifiers aren't showing price adjustments

Verify that: 1. The source product had price adjustments configured 2. The modifier type supports price adjustments (some don't) 3. The adjustment values weren't zero

Complex rules not working after migration

Check the following: 1. Modifiers migrated: Complex rules depend on modifiers existing first 2. ID mapping: If modifier migration failed, rule conditions may reference invalid IDs 3. Rule enabled: Verify the rule's "enabled" flag is true 4. Conditions met: Test the exact modifier combination that should trigger the rule

Solution: Re-migrate the product to ensure modifiers and rules are properly linked.

Product not appearing on storefront

Check these settings: - Is Visible: Product visibility flag - Channel Assignment: Product must be assigned to the storefront channel - Category: Product should be in a visible category - Inventory: If tracking is enabled, verify stock quantity

Custom fields not displaying

Custom fields may not display automatically. Verify: 1. Custom fields were migrated (check product in admin) 2. Your theme is configured to display custom fields 3. The field names match what your theme expects

I lost data after updating a product - can I recover it?

If a product was updated (not created), a backup was taken: 1. Use the rollback feature with the migration ID 2. Original product data will be restored 3. Components restored: base data, options, variants, modifiers, custom fields, bulk pricing, videos

Note: Images and reviews are NOT rolled back (they're only added, never deleted).

Why are my destination product variants all gone?

In UPDATE mode, all options are deleted before migration, which automatically deletes all variants. This is expected behavior: - Variants are recreated from source - Inventory levels from source are applied - Option value mappings are fresh

If source had fewer variants than destination, only source variants will exist after migration.

Metafields from apps aren't working

App-specific metafields may require: 1. Same app installed in destination store 2. App to have matching client ID 3. Proper permission settings

If the creating app isn't installed, metafields exist but may not function as expected.

Best Practices Before Migration

  1. Verify source data: Ensure products have complete data

  2. Check images: Confirm all image URLs are accessible

  3. Review inventory: Know your current stock levels

  4. Document custom templates: Note which templates your products use

During Migration

  1. Start small: Test with a few products first

  2. Monitor progress: Check migration status regularly

  3. Review results: Verify migrated products look correct

After Migration

  1. Spot check products: Review several products in detail

  2. Test purchasing: Add products to cart, check pricing

  3. Verify images: Confirm all images display correctly

  4. Check variants: Test option selection and variant switching

  5. Review SEO: Confirm page titles and meta descriptions

Still Have Questions?

When contacting support, please provide: - Source and destination store identifiers - Product IDs you're trying to migrate - Any error messages you've encountered - Screenshots if applicable

We're here to help ensure a smooth migration!

This guide provides practical examples of common BigCommerce product migration scenarios with real-world examples.

Use Case 1: Single Product Migration

Scenario: You need to copy one specific product from your staging store to your production store, or from one store to another.

What Gets Migrated

Component

  - WH-PRO-2024-RSG → Color: Rose Gold - $159.99, Stock: 20

Images: All 5 re-uploaded with alt text preserved
Important Notes

  • Product ID changes but all data is preserved

  • Option and variant IDs are mapped automatically

  • Brand and categories are matched by name or created

Use Case 9: Product with Complex Rules (Conditional Pricing)

Scenario: Migrating a customizable product where certain modifier combinations trigger special pricing, weight changes, or purchasing restrictions.

Source Product 
Product: Custom Engraved Watch
Base Price: $299.99

Modifiers:
- Watch Band Material (Dropdown):
  - Leather ($0)
  - Stainless Steel (+$50)
  - Titanium (+$150)

- Engraving Style (Dropdown):
  - None ($0)
  - Simple Text (+$25)
  - Cursive Script (+$45)
  - Custom Logo (+$75)

- Gift Box (Checkbox):

Complex Rules:
1. "Premium Package" Rule:
   - IF Band = "Titanium" AND Engraving = "Custom Logo"
   - THEN: Add $25 (premium handling fee)

2. "Heavy Item" Rule:
   - IF Band = "Stainless Steel" OR Band = "Titanium"
   - THEN: Add 0.5 lbs to shipping weight

3. "Discontinued Combo" Rule:
   - IF Band = "Leather" AND Engraving = "Custom Logo"
   - THEN: Disable purchasing, show message "This combination is not available"

Step 1: Modifiers Created First

Source Modifier "Watch Band Material" (ID: 100) → Destination (ID: 500)

    - Modifier 500, Value 503 (Titanium)
    - Modifier 600, Value 604 (Custom Logo)

Rule 2 "Heavy Item":
  Conditions:
    - Modifier 500, Value 502 (Stainless Steel) OR
    - Modifier 500, Value 503 (Titanium)

Rule 3 "Discontinued Combo":
  Conditions:
    - Modifier 500, Value 501 (Leather)
    - Modifier 600, Value 604 (Custom Logo)
  Purchasing Disabled: true
  Message: "This combination is not available"

All complex rules function identically: - Customer selects Titanium + Custom Logo → $25 added to price - Customer selects Stainless Steel → 0.5 lbs added to weight - Customer selects Leather + Custom Logo → Add to Cart disabled with message

Use Case 10: Updating Existing Products

Scenario: A product already exists in the destination store, and you want to update it with data from the source store.

How Update Mode Works

Step 1: Product Resolution

Source Product: "Summer Dress Collection" (SKU: SDC-2024)

Destination Search:
1. Search by name "Summer Dress Collection" → Found! (ID: 456)
2. Mode: UPDATE (not CREATE)

Step 2: Backup Created Before any changes, existing product data is backed up: - Product base information - All options and variants - Modifiers and complex rules - Custom fields - Bulk pricing rules - Videos

Important: The backup ensures you can rollback if something goes wrong.

Step 3: Component Cleanup (DELETE Phase)

This is a critical step. In UPDATE mode, existing components are completely deleted before new ones are created. This is a replace strategy, not a merge.

Component

Cleanup Action

Images

ALL existing images deleted

Options

ALL options deleted

Variants

Auto-deleted when options removed

Modifiers

ALL modifiers deleted

Custom Fields

ALL custom fields deleted

Bulk Pricing Rules

ALL rules deleted

Videos

ALL videos deleted

Why delete everything? This ensures a clean slate and prevents orphaned data, duplicate entries, or mismatched IDs. The source data becomes the single source of truth.

Step 4: New Components Created Fresh data from source is created: - New options with new IDs - New variants linked to new options - New modifiers with new IDs - New complex rules with mapped modifier IDs - New custom fields - New bulk pricing rules - New videos - Product and variant metafields

Step 5: Images Added - Source images are uploaded fresh - Display order and alt text preserved

Understanding the Replace Strategy

Example: Before and After

Before Migration (Destination):

Product: Summer Dress Collection
Options: Size (S, M, L), Color (Red, Blue)
Variants: 6 variants
Modifiers: Gift Wrap, Custom Message
Custom Fields: Material, Care Instructions

After Migration (From Source):

Product: Summer Dress Collection (UPDATED)
Options: Size (XS, S, M, L, XL), Color (Red, Blue, Green)  ← Different!
Variants: 15 variants  ← More variants!
Modifiers: Gift Wrap, Rush Processing  ← Different modifiers!
Custom Fields: Fabric, Season, Designer  ← Different fields!

The destination product now exactly matches the source, regardless of what was there before.

Rollback Option

If the update causes issues: 1. Trigger rollback using migration ID 2. Original product data restored from backup 3. Product returns to pre-migration state

What gets restored: - Product base information - All original options and variants - Original modifiers - Original custom fields - Original bulk pricing rules - Original videos

What is NOT restored: - Images (only added, not modified) - Reviews (only added) - Custom template associations

Important Notes

  • Always verify source data before updating production products

  • Test with a sample product first

  • Backup is retained until explicitly cleaned up

  • Complex rules are handled intelligently to avoid duplicates

docs.title: Migration Types - Bulk Migration vs Selective Migration
Bulk Migration (Migration that creates records in an empty destination store)
docs.text:
• When you perform a Bulk migration, StagingPro assumes the entities are not present in the destination and the StagingPro app will simply create them on the target store. If the entities already exist, it will show error notifications. There is no update action for existing entities.
  • When you select ‘Products’, by default, the product stock inventory count wont migrate. Use Selective Migration for Products instead.
  • NOTE: New Product ids are linked to orders during Bulk Content Migration

  • Data Dependencies

    There are many cases where data migration may cause a conflict unless related data is migrated simultaneously. An example of this is the relationship between a product and its variations or a product and its categories. A summary list of dependencies can be found below.

Sl.No Selected Entity Dependant Entities Migrated Automatically 1 Products Brands, Categories 2 Product Reviews Brands, Categories, Products 3 Price List Records Brands, Categories, Products, Price Lists 4 Price List Assignments Price Lists, Customer Groups 5 Customers Customer Groups 6 Shipping Methods Shipping Zones 7 Promotions Brands, Categories, Products, Customer Groups, Shipping Zones

docs.title: Selective Migration (Migration that updates records in the destination store)
docs.text:
• Products

    • If products already exist on the destination store, it will updated during a migration. Products with multiple variation items will be deleted and recreated on the target store.
    • Selective Product Migration now features the ‘Copy All Products’ button, which means you can run a selective update on all products now, as an on-demand task
    • Now by default (Product Stock count wont migrate unless you specify the checkbox value on the popup 'Migrate Product Stock inventory count to target store'
    • As it relates to product images, if you delete product images on the source store SKU and perform a Selective Product migration, the corresponding product images will not be deleted from the destination SKU. As an example,
    • lets say you have a SKU with 10 images on source store which you have performed a selective migration to destination.
    • If you remove 5 images from the source SKU and repeat the Selective Product Migration, the corresponding images are not removed from the destination store. You need to delete these images manually on the destination store

  • Promotions

    • With current behaviour, promotions that exist in the source store are migrated to the destination store

  • Categories

    • If categories exist in the destination store, you can use this option to update the categories on the target store
    • When migrating the category from source to destination, if the category already exists at the destination inside another parent category, then StagingPro creates a category with the same name as per the source category structure in the destination.
    • In this case you will have two categories in the destination with same name.
    • StagingPro will not delete the old category in the destination, it remains same.
    • IMPORTANT NOTE: When performing a ‘Selective Migration (Categories)’, only the checkboxed user-selected Categories will move to the destination store. Hence, if you want the Products associated with these Categories to migrate as well, then:
    • As a follow-up step, you must next perform the ‘Selective Migration (Products’) for those respective Categories.
      • But remember when performing the ‘Selective Migration’ of these Products, the associated categories will be overwritten (not appended) at the destination.
      • Hence review your product-category associations on the source store before performing a ‘Selective Product Migration’ to destination

  • Custom Pages and Page Templates

    • You can use this to migrate Custom pages from Source store + storefront to destination.
    • You can select ‘Migrate Global Widgets’ depending on your migration preference
    • IMPORTANT note, this option only applies to older customers not using the new Page Widgets API. This option is a default selection when your stores are whitelisted to use the new Page Widgets API
    • Page content (text) is updated if the page already exists. If it does not exist, a new page is created. With respect to widgets and widget templates, all existing widgets contained within a page will be removed and recreated again
    • Homepage should be a selectable option under ‘Page Templates’ tab

Important

For reliable Pages migration we highly recommend you use the new Page Widgets API. Send your store hashes to our Helpdesk Team so it is whitelisted on both BigCommerce as well as our StagingPro systems. Once whitelisting is confirmed, you can use the new Page Widgets API for improved migration accuracy.

  • Themes
    • You can migrate Themes selectively from your source to destination BigCommerce store.
    • Select the Theme of your choice and use the ‘Copy Theme’ button to start the migration

Please ensure that: You do not store important, business critical or development essential data on a sandbox store as this is for test migrations only! Keep your configuration settings safe elsewhere.

If there is any information we need to be aware before granting access to our tech team for troubleshooting e.g.,

i) data on staging that you’re team is actively working on and you wish to retain

ii) your development workflow processes we need to be aware of,

please let us know before access is granted and our testing begins.

docs.title: Best practice naming conventions and testing guidance in StagingPro environments
docs.text:
As best practice and to avoid confusion, you can use the following naming conventions to clearly label your StagingPro environments.

  • Production - use this name for your live store site which contains all finished and approved codes/data. This is the default system name and cannot be changed/altered to any other value
  • Staging - use this name for your pre-deployment site that is setup to mimic your live site configurations and used for your smoke tests before deployment to ‘Production'
  • UAT - use this name for your site configured to run as a production build with a separate database. Used by clients to check that feature requests are working as expected before deployment to ‘Staging’
  • Integration - use this name for your site configured for system integration tests and checks for functional/non-functional elements before deployment to ‘UAT’.
  • You can also label your integration environments with numeric values, e.g. Integration1, Integration2

Screenshot provided for ease of reference.

IMPORTANT!As an additional best practice, it is highly recommended to test migrations first to non-Production environments. This helps you to gain a better understanding of StagingPro’s functionality, while safely launching/reviewing your test migrations. Only after comprehensive testing and proper validation in non-Production environments, should you migrate data to a live Production environment.
